It seems Christians should avoid yoga and meditation, but stretching that isn't yoga is ok, as well as relaxing that isn't meditation - the key would be not adding in the Hindu or Buddhist influences.

"Yoga" refers to "hatha yoga", a hindu kind of stretching. There are other "yogas" which aren't stretching ("karma yoga" is a yoga of working as religious practice, or "raja yoga" which I think is some kind of intellectual activity). Maybe like someone might say they want to play "Nintendo" when they mean video games in general (actually this analogy is backwards, from a particular to a general term, whereas "yoga" is a general term being used for the specific term of "hatha yoga"). Anyway, "hatha yoga" isn't just stretching, but is a religious practice of hindus. So, it seems like that would be avoided by Christians as being directly non-Christian, or at least due to doubt that some kind of conflicting practice wouldn't be mixed in. 

Now, the only overlap I'd like to mention is, say I do a non-yoga stretch, and then it's almost the same as or is the same as some kind of yoga stretch. I imagine there are a limit of the amount of effective stretches that exist. I guess it could end up being like "doing yoga without doing yoga", if that makes any sense. It's not like hindus or the hindu religion get to trademark the stretches as part of their religion, and if you do a stretch that overlaps with a yoga stretch, I don't think it's yoga exactly. 

Meditation, or specifically "transcendental meditation" is a Buddhist religious practice. Sometimes, either yoga or meditation are part of other non-Christian religious traditions (New Age practice comes to mind). Again, it would seem that there could be conflicts with views here, whereas sometimes Buddhist monks might meditate for hours a day instead of pray for hours a day as Christian monks would do, due to different fundamental beliefs that lead to different actions. It seems Christians should avoid meditative practices.

Another confusion is the word "meditation", which in the West is used to mean "meditative prayer", which is something different entirely. (For the Catholic view, see ["mental prayer" on the prayer encyclopedia entry](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12345b.htm)). I suspect the buddhist word of "meditation" may be a deliberately chosen confused translation, but I don't really know for sure, if anyone has any knowledge on the history of translating the word.

As with yoga, meditation seems to have an overlap with non-meditative relaxation. It's not exactly the same as meditation to close your eyes, relax, take some deep breaths, and clear your mind, or "zone out" - although these seem to overlap with Buddhist meditation. Again, I don't think Buddhists have a "trademark" on relaxation, but it seems the Eastern tradition has made it in to a major practice of their religion.

I think it has been concerning to see yoga and meditation casually suggested as "therapies" for those with mental issues today; it seems to create more and more of divides between Christian and non-Christian society (although there are some non-Christian therapists who might have the open mind enough to understand a potential conflict exists between these suggestions and the faith of a Christian patient).

Now, on the other hand, Christianity has had a tendency to "baptize" certain things (to take a non-Christian thing and make it in to a Christian thing), so I don't know if that could be done with yoga and meditation, but I don't think it has been done at present. I don't think it's needed - you can stretch without yoga, and relax without meditation. That seems enough to me, and I don't see a compelling reason why Christians should practice yoga and meditation when they have ties to non-Christian religions. 

Do you think that Christians should avoid yoga and meditation? What other topics should be mentioned for discussion?

I kind of agree in theory, but in practice am not always sure where the line should be drawn.

Consider some arguments against rock music (specifically):

The "and Roll" in "Rock n' Roll" referred to fornication:

Many people don't know that the term rock-n-roll was also a slang word for [the reproductive act] in the late 1940s and early 1950s. It was particularly used by teens or the younger people in those days similar to the way people today use the word "freak" [or maybe, hook up?]. https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=rock-n-roll

Many lyrics promote sin or godlessness (I think everyone agrees these can be a clear issue)

The culture of rock has promoted open rebellion to authority (sins of pride)

Culture of rock has promoted sins of drunkenness ("sex, drugs, and rock 'n roll")

Prominent rock musicians like the Beatles and Led Zeppelin's members have dabbled with the occult or used occult imagery

The sound of rock is aggressive rather than promoting virtues of meekness and peacefulness

The rhythms of rock are said to be sensual or incite lust and encourage people to engage in the reproductive act

Rock can encourage unbridled passion, which can lead to sin (of too much anger, leading to acts of violence like in mosh pits or outside of them, or of too much sadness, which can lead to sins of despair or hopelessness)

Rock musicians have created a culture that pushed anti-Christian political and religious values

Heavy metal rock music was used to torture people by the military: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-40090809

I think you get the idea (mention more points if I forgot something that should be mentioned?)

Other genres like techno and rap might have the same kind of issues. Rock comes from jazz and I know some conservatives were even against jazz. The Nazis thought jazz was "degenerate art", I think: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degenerate_music I imagine other non-Nazi conservatives were also against music like this for less controversial reasons (they just thought the music was immoral).

Degenerate music (German: Entartete Musik, German pronunciation: [ɛntˈaʁtɛtə muˈziːk]) was a label applied in the 1930s by the Nazi government in Germany to certain forms of music that it considered harmful or decadent.

In the same vein, certain books have been banned throughout history for promoting "subversive" ideas: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_books_banned_by_governments

Regardless if the books ought to be banned or not, we might agree that their contents at times promoted sin and immorality and that they were "bad books".

Even some classical pieces might be subject to the same problems, like "modern" classical forms that are chaotic (maybe like "serialism" pieces? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serialism)

With rock, I think the lyrics could be a clear problem, and maybe some of the drums. A counter-example would be something like "Christian rock" - is this a contradiction, like "Satanic Christianity"? Moreover, do you think God wants people to be making rock music?

In contrast, music approved for church might be an example of music that wouldn't be problematic - if there are doubts about rock music, would it be better to try to find music you have no doubts about?

Are you persuaded by rock music and other musics being bad, or if not what is your problem with it?
